content: hi
what's the agenda for today btw? I've been "having a few thoughts"
(pertaining esp. to domain wgs)

Hello everyone,

It's time for the @WG-governance meeting! React/Reply with :wave: to indicate your attendance.
@WG-governance
I'll get that right eventually.
In terms of agenda, there's only really followup.
We could definitely use this time to have a discussion on domain wgs, or the MCP/Pre-RFC topics.
One of the other things that has been happening is some work around prioritization
e.g., in the lang team, we started looking at what our upcoming initiatives should be, and i'm trying to focus an effort like this in compiler team
Are you referring to the prioritization WG specifically or project wide prioritization?
I raise it because, in doing it, I had thoughts about the role of working groups or other structures
lol, so many priorities
I'm sort of referring to neither of those things, but more the latter
#t-lang > prioritization is the t-lang topic, but the key document is this hackmd
still very much a draft
anyway I don't want to go too deep-- should we maybe agree to spend N minutes though on domain wgs recap?
I believe @Val Grimm didn't get to it in time for this meeting.
So we could defer that, unless someone has something specific about it they want to mention.
The only followup I have is the Project Group RFC has finished FCP.
that's fine, the main thing I wanted to mention is that --in looking at that lang team list -- I see some things, like "error handling"
that have the following interesting characteristics:
• they are cross-cutting, involving a coordinated story across multiple teams
• they probably involve a number of independent changes and improvements, i.e., multiple RFCs
this might just be a "project group"
but it also seems to look a lot to me like a domain working group

I don't know, I keep getting a bit frustrated because there seem to be a need for a few different sorts of structures -- or maybe they're variations on a single structure, or maybe they can just be informal
but I feel like the idea of 'commisioning' an effort to address some area/big-problem is a decent one
That is interesting. I guess this sort of brings up "what is the end-goal of a WG?" that is unclear right now.

I think where domain working groups have maybe gone astray is a bit the "bottom up" part of it, it seems like they should really represent "priority areas for Rust", and perhaps also the longevity side of it
i.e., it's not clear when they are 'done'
error handling might be one that has a done state

mostly I wanted to raise this because I think in the past there's been a definite sense of "maybe we should just not have domain WGs", I know i've thought it from time to time, and it may be true, but I think there's a useful need to handle these "cross-cutting" sort of things, and it's worth thinking about how they're modeled
and I think this group itself fits in that category of course :)

error handling might be one that has a done state

Does it? I'm don't mean that in a snarky way, but genuinely how do you define done in that case?
well
I think in that case there could be a set of problems to be addressed

e.g., done is when there is a document that defines best-practices for how error handling should work and a set of lang features that enable it, such taht the following is true

  • there is a "best practice" to accumulate errors from multiple crates
  • there is a syntactically convenient way to propagate errors
  • ...
it ain't super easy but I at least have a sense of a "set of features" that constitute a scope, and I suspect they could be turned into a kind of set of problems to attack
(even if some of those features wound up not being accepted, hopefully the problem is still resolvedin some way, or we decide it's not so bad)
one could plausibly do a similar thing for async
(but it seems somewhat harder to me)
it might be a good exercise for this group, of course, to try and enumerate the problems we're aiming to tackle
(evergreen)
I feel like a project group is one that would have a "done" state
while a working group would not have a "done" state - it is meant to persist as the language changes and grows
yes, this has been my sense
and it's precisely why we introduced the term 'project group'
so maybe the answer is that 'error handling is a project group' -- and maybe "async foundations" should be recast in that vein?
(if we could enumerate some goals)
one thing I have found a real need for is a group that sticks around to handle particular kinds of tasks -- e.g., the 'priotiziation working group' in compiler or triage wg in release
(though that could even be considered a "subteam"...)

mostly I wanted to raise this because I think in the past there's been a definite sense of "maybe we should just not have domain WGs"

I've also been thinking about that. Not that we shouldn't have cross-cutting groups but I feel that current iteration has been more about bringing in new groups and members, rather than bringing together teams.
current iteration of domain WGs?
Yes
I wonder
meh, nm. I was going to say "maybe we should try to have some reps attend this meeting to chat"
but I feel like maybe we need a bit more of an..agenda?
Agreed
Yeah, that feels like something we should plan for, if not the next meeting, then the meeting after.
It may be good to propose definitions for working groups/project groups and then get the feedback of reps
that way it gives us a starting point
we can certainly iterate on those definitions
but I have found in order to get the most engaged feedback, there needs to be some sort of starting point.
I think the "indefinite" vs "definite" distinction is solid, but I think perhaps more than a definition, we should be talking about
• what is the role we expect them to play
(Sometimes the best way to get people to engage meaningfully on something is to give them something to object to)
• how do they interact with teams

Hm, here's an alternate, narrower distinction:

  • Project groups have a clear roadmap with a small set of known outputs (e.g. language features)
  • Domain groups have known _goals_, but these don't correspond to known _features_. So the error-handling goals you listed above, Niko, would fall more in this category.
interesting
(sorry, got a phone call in the middle of typing that so I'm responding to something a page or so up)
How about as part of @Val Grimm's email to the WG reps we also invite them to a meeting? so that will give us people's thoughts ahead of the meeting that we can build agenda ahead of time.
I feel like we should not give ourselves a deadline
Well, maybe we sohuld, but I'm not necessarily ready to commit to meeting it
if others want to that's good
i.e., if the idea is to have a starting point before ...
@nikomatsakis i think we should not have arbitrary new domain WGs
like, no application procedure
I agree with that
i also think a lot of team concerns can be cross cutting, error handling as a libs team project group would work
I think it matters a bit more than that perhaps

Well, maybe we sohuld, but I'm not necessarily ready to commit to meeting it

Heh, that's fine. I could commit to it, but I'm also in no particular rush to get it done asap.
I thnk it's worth stating up front like "lang changes are in scope, let's have some lang team liaison"
but I feel like maybe it's good to outline all the different "sorts of groups" one could have. I definitely think having too many names will just confuse people too :P
/me says the guy who loves to make new names
yeah
I started jotting things here
Yeah, I think having teams more actively participating is something that is missing in working groups.
Because on WG side they can often feel like they don't know who to escalate their change request to, having liaisons would remedy some of that.
One side note I've found for the async area
there is a lot of work involved there, ranging from compiler team polish, to libs/lang design, to exploring and learning about applications, to documentation etc
and it's harder to mix those concerns than you might think :)
you wind up with de-facto "subgroups", for sure

anyway, I guess I am feeling this itchy feeling like "should we determine some concrete next step" -- I think we were going to reach out to the existing domain wg leads again? is that still the "next step"?
I think the next step is reaching out to the WG leads
but we also should decide what we want to say in that outreach
what kind of feedback/ideas are we looking for from them?
I made a draft of that I thought?
sweet!
the questionnaire etc?
or should I add more?
I think we should still reach out, but maybe should also try to define what "we"/"the rust org" wants out of a domain WG?
let's talk about that draft :)

XAMPPRocky said:

I think we should still reach out, but maybe should also try to define what "we"/"the rust org" wants out of a domain WG?

ah ok
What I think I'm hearing - we "the rust org" want a domain working group to be a long lasting, cross functional group with liasons that various teams can reach out to
yes, and, specifically, for team priorities
does that sound correct?
like, there should not be an application process imo
if you want a WG it's up to you to convince teams that it's a cross functional thing that needs one, and the teams can convince core
sounds good
@Val Grimm is the draft available in hackmd or paper or something?
its here in Zulip
folks commented on it

Agreed - but for a general definition (without getting into the process of creating one just yet) - does "a long lasting, cross functional group with liasons that various teams can reach out to" work?
https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/223182-wg-governance/topic/domain.20working.20group.20followup/near/196103938
thank you!
I can put it in Hack.md for editing if that would help, I imagine that would, or paste it here
that draft looks good to me, with the suggestions in the Zulip thread incorporated
I think a doc would be better
I mostly wnated to be able to see what is the 'updated version' etc
(dropbox paper is good for its comment system, in my experience)
ok, I've not used that but I can set it up if one can do that for free.
you need a dropbox account

a long lasting, cross functional group with liasons that various teams can reach out to

Agree, at least as a broad overview
And I'm glad I was slow and hadn't already sent it
but that is free
ah darn
but hackmd is fine too :)
ah ok, I can set up an account, I'll do that after this meeting*
I think the answer is @Val Grimm feel free to put it in whatever platform you are most comfortable with - whether dropbox papers or hackmd
(or google...though we don't tend to use that as much)
I'll put it somewhere ans share URL in domain working group ffollowup
Sounds like we have a general definition of a working group and a next step - does that seem correct to everyone else?
So to backup a little bit, I also agree with cutting the application process, it hasn't really worked great so far.
yes

PS, @Manish Goregaokar, speaking of the act of creating a group or what have you-- I am reminded of how, in the proposed lang-team procedure, the first step to making an RFC isn't..well..make an RFC, it's to create a "proposal" (which we may opt to select and pursue). I sort of feel this should be how all teams work, and I wonder then if "making a domain working group" (or whatever) is just another RFC -- i.e., it's a kind of proposal you make to core team, which team may opt to pursue (or not).
@Nell Shamrell-Harrington What's the next step? Reaching out? I think maybe we should try to make a fleshed out definition of WG.
I'm fine with either of those - just trying to drive us to a decision on the "next step"
Do we want to include our definition of a domain WG in the message?
next step in my mind is send message
and do it before the next meeting
Sorry I meant in addition, not an either or
ah ok
ah, cool

it sounds like next steps are

  • complete draft of reach out email (including definition of WG)
  • send to WG leads and whoever else is appropriate
  • continue fleshing out definition of WG
I'll incorp info from this meeting and the thread and then share the link
Cutting the application process also does bring up how to communicate these changes, as we have had two applicant groups that have been sitting in limbo for awhile now.
that should be a separate message
Also, is there a decision on those applicants?
would be best to give answer on that before message
This came up in a core team meeting recently. I think the feeling there was that we're basically going to say that we're not going to create any domain working groups
because governance wg is pursuing the question
that works for me
of what their role should be and so forth
it might in some sense be helpful to have a message or blog post to point to
but I guess our minutes and so forth suffice
We need at least a message to include in the applicant issues on the wg repo. Since those need to closed.
Right.
yes
where else do we talk about the "application process"
we would also want to update those docs
hm maybe on forge
looking
(on azerty laptop so typing issues sorry)
I would guess mainly on the wg-governance repo.
The most detailed information about the process is @Florian Gilcher's original application thread on discourse.
I think .. yes, I was going to say "internals"
so an action item is to prepare an updated message for the two issues and perhaps for the internals thread
yes
someone with more knowledge of the issues needs to write those responses I think

we're about out of time but I feel like it'd be useful to have a bit of a sketch of our current plan for this larger effort that we have posted somewhere -- kind of, this is the process, these are the questions
I can try to write those reponses I guess
doesn't seem too hard :)
cool
Yeah, I would also say I think those messages should come from a representative on the core team, to better communicate where the change comes from.
yes
the internals post I can try and send here for ok
I'll include it in the doc with the email message
sound good?
seems fine, though i'm not 100% sure which internals post you mean :)
I thought an internals post was needed?

nikomatsakis said:

so an action item is to prepare an updated message for the two issues and perhaps for the internals thread

seeing this
I think niko volunteered for both (thanks!)
ah ok good
I think that's more authoritative, thus better
yes, I did
Okay, we have a bit over 5 minutes left, is there anything else we should bring up before we close the meeting?
cool, I'll just deal with the email message and getting the blog post up (faster than last time, where I forgot to push the patch to the PR)
btw so many thanks for the blog posts

Okay to reiterate the action items

  • blog post
  • complete draft of reach out email (including definition of WG)
  • send to WG leads and whoever else is appropriate
  • continue fleshing out definition of WG
  • Announce domain wg application closure.
one thing I wanted to mention is that
(not an action item!)
if folks are interestd in the lang team proposal process we were discussing --
there is plan to talk about it in the next lang team design meeting, which I think is Monday =)
though we've been talking about rescheduling so .. check the calendar I guess
Yeah I wanted to maybe talk about that more but we had a pretty good discussion on domain wgs.
The proposal process meaning this? https://hackmd.io/vtE1YgufTU-q_u-NOXqW8A?view
correct
:thumbs_up:
Okay, I'm going to call the meeting here. Thank you everyone for attending, and see you again next time. Stay safe!
Thank you for leading, @XAMPPRocky!
